presentations.title: Open Source Satellite Initiative
presentations.description: OSSI project presented at Art Spectrum, Leeum Museum of Art
presentations.overview:
The core idea of the OSSI satellite project is to share the entire process of building and launching a satellite. Therefore, even though it was presented in a renowned exhibition such as Art Spectrum, the work was presented in a deliberately approachable and accessible manner. The main idea behind the presentation format was inspired by kiosks found in local community offices and post offices. 
By encouraging active audience participation‚Äîwatching videos and solving quizzes‚Äîthe project aimed to help viewers realize that the technologies discussed in the satellite project are in fact connected to broader themes such as society, politics, and people‚Äôs dreams.
![Satellite Quiz Show Communication Module Capter](QuizShowLeeum.jpg)
![Satellite Quiz Show Communication Module Capter](OSSIQuizshowPeople.JPG)
![Satellite Quiz Show Communication Module Capter](OSSIQuizshowPeople2.JPG)

presentations.title: Open Source Satellite Initiative
presentations.description: OSSI project presented at Objectology 2
presentations.overview:
OSSI-1 Satellite Manufacturing Techniques, 2015
This work presents stories about manufacturing techniques based on practical knowledge of satellite construction. Rather than focusing on the operating principles of satellites, it highlights hands-on processes such as wire selection, wire stripping, soldering, aluminum machining, spring fabrication, antenna making, and selecting adhesives capable of functioning in space. 
These forms of practical knowledge‚Äîoften referred to as know-how‚Äîare much harder to find than theoretical principles organized in textbooks. The exhibition presents actual fabricated satellite components alongside stories of the people, communities, and online knowledge encountered throughout the production process.

The artist‚Äôs core approach‚Äîcreating narratives through technology‚Äîlies in hoping that the simultaneous switching on and off of multiple devices resonates with the many stories of the world. works.title: Future School Food Foraging - Seaweed
works.description: Seaweeds like Miyeok and Dasima are now considered among the most invasive species globally, yet they are traditional postpartum food in Korea.
overview: Seaweeds like Miyeok (Undaria pinnatifida) and Dasima (Laminaria japonica) travel with ocean currents and settle wherever they land. Now considered among the most invasive species globally, they are also traditional postpartum food in Korea.
We know that ocean seaweed captures more carbon than the Amazon rainforest, yet few international institutions officially recognize this.
It's striking how this seemingly insignificant seaweed connects to major global issues: future food, climate change, decolonization, and diaspora.

works.title: Don't Compress Me
works.description: Participants try to create movements for 10 seconds that resist video compression.
overview: > ‚ÄúHow can we think and act In the age of A.I. ?‚Äù
Participants try to create movements for 10 seconds that resist video compression. They stand before a camera and record; the person whose video stays largest after compression wins.
Random movements should defeat codecs like H.264, but there's an irony: once people consciously try to be random, they can't truly be random.
![Don't Compress Me World Competition, 2022](01-Don't Compress Me World Poster.jpg)

The competition has been held all over the world, including:
* Basel, Switzerland üá®üá≠
* Goa, India üáÆüá≥
* Rome, Italy üáÆüáπ
* Seoul and Daejeon, South Korea üá∞üá∑

In 2022, Don't Compress Me World Competition started.
 
The artist Hojun Song says he started the competition to find a human who can live beyond the predictions of artificial intelligence.
The competition will continue to be held in various cities around the world.
The winner in each city will receive 1 Ethereum as a prize, and the winner of the World Series to be held in Korea will receive 1 Bitcoin.
> Join the ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Compress Me‚Äù competition to become a New Human.
The work, contemplated since 2009, was first realized and presented at Future Now, Berlin, 2015.
![Don't Compress Me, 2015](01-Don't Compress Me 2015.png)
Unlike the regular "Don't Compress Me" competition where participants use their entire body, this version requires participants to move only their head for 10 seconds to resist video compression.
Artists from various countries participated in the competition, and certain patterns seemed to emerge in their movements and sound.
![Don't Compress Me Head Only Blackout Basel, 2015](all.jpg)
At "Don't Compress," shown at Unfold X in late 2025, many people participated in groups. Individuals could not overcome the dynamics of the group.
[video][Don't Compress Me Group Section Winner, UnfoldX, 2025](DCMWC_UnfoldX2025_977_rank_2_1742KB.mp4)

works.description: gold & silver is a two-member experimental improvisation band: Hojun Song and Sangback Choe.
overview: gold & silver is a two-member experimental improvisation band: Hojun Song and Sangback Choe. The band makes experimental music accessible by actively explaining what they're doing and why during performances.

works.title: For Humanity - Einstein Merong
works.description: Even after the Trinity test revealed the bomb's power, and even after Germany's defeat, the Manhattan Project continued. The question remains: couldn't these geniuses have stopped it?
overview: Even after the Trinity test revealed the bomb's power, and even after Germany's defeat, the Manhattan Project continued‚Äîdropping nuclear bombs on two Japanese cities. works.title: Poomba
works.description: Winner of the Ilmac Art Prize 2015, Hojun Song's solo exhibition featured no physical artworks. The poomba was a Korean figure: satirist, clown, beggar, and street monk.
overview: Winner of the Ilmac Art Prize 2015, Hojun Song's solo exhibition featured no physical artworks. Deconstructing heroes and restoring romance collided‚Äîthe artist could only ask questions, since making and showing things felt like violence. The poomba was a Korean figure from the late Goryeo dynasty: satirist, clown, beggar, and street monk, respected for wisdom. A self-deprecating, hero-deconstructing hero. The exhibition explored what a future poomba might be. Four talks and four workshops were held at the gallery and a nearby construction site, all live-streamed. Activities included camping and swimming at the construction site, with nightly gatherings for drinks.

works.title: LED That Blinks Once Every 100 Years
works.description: A small, cheap 5mm LED that blinks once every 100 years. The project was rejected after Hojun Song refused to make the LED blink every year instead.
overview: ![LED That Blinks Once Every 100 Years Proposal, 2014](100yearsLEDAssem3.jpg)

A small, cheap 5mm LED that blinks once every 100 years. The idea began in 2010 and nearly became a public art project in 2015. A two-meter spherical structure would house an LED module in an inert gas-filled vacuum chamber. Nuclear batteries would provide 100 years of power, with a passive heating system designed through thermal simulation. The project was rejected after Hojun Song refused the committee's proposal to make it blink every year.
![LED that blinks once every 100 years ver 001, 2025](01-LED-that-blinks-once-every-100-years ver 001.jpeg)
Twelve years later in 2026, [the first version](/works/led-that-blinks-once-every-100-years/2025-Ver001/) was built.
> The first light was emitted at 8:00 PM on January 14, 2026. The next blink will occur at the same time on **January 14, 2126**.
![The First Blink, 14th Jan 2026 20:00:00 (KST)](FirstBlink43.jpg)
![The First Blink at Galaxy Coporation, 2026](100YearsBlink.jpg)

presentations.wherehowbecomeswhy:
> Engineers solve how. Artists decide why. In this project, those roles blur‚Äîor reverse. A technical choice becomes a philosophical statement.
Choosing solar power over nuclear batteries is an engineering decision. But it makes the device mortal‚Äîit can die without care. That's a philosophical statement. How becomes why.
This is an extremely technical project but to ask a real question about finite lives and fragile digital history, it cannot stay as concept. It has to be built. Work like this needs artists and scientists together. 
A **forum** is planned where scientists and artists will meet to discuss building the next versions.
![The LED That Blinks Every 100 Years PCB, 2026](IMG_6925.jpeg)
presentations.designing100-yearelectronicsisanexistent:
> 100 years‚Äîabout as long as a person lives. 
Making electronics last that long requires endless decisions. Resistors, capacitors, solder, wires, enclosure materials, inert gas, temperature control. Every component matters.
We don't think this hard about our own bodies. We already know our lifespan.
But electronics feel different. 100 years seems possible. So we try. We calculate. We choose materials. We design for survival.
Especially if we just want to light an LED‚Äîit seems feasible.
The whole process of making it becomes the practice. Every day, it makes you think about life, death, and what remains.
And when it finally blinks, you realize how sacred a simple LED can be.
![Strongest Weapon - Rosetta Stone Workshop, 2009](3890105674_d62d3bb7a3_o.jpg)

![LED that blinks once every 100 years  Assembly, 2025](LEDAssemble.jpg)
> To run for 100 years, the crucial part is making digital memory last that long. And finding a power source that lasts 100 years.
Flash memory lasts only about 20 years. FRAM can last 100 years. A low-power Real Time Clock keeps time. It wakes the FRAM microcontroller only to check if today is the day.
Regular batteries die too soon. Nuclear batteries last a century, but this version uses supercapacitors instead‚Äîthey can charge and discharge forever.
High-efficiency solar cells and an energy harvesting controller let it charge from weak indoor light.
It faces the sun during the day, lives off that energy at night. If no one looks after it, it could die anytime.
To prolong memory retention, it stays at 25¬∞C while facing the sun. The design borrows from NASA's James Webb telescope sun shield.
To stop corrosion from air, the enclosure uses hermetic sealing‚Äîan ultra-high vacuum seal that even hydrogen and helium can't get through.
presentations.keepingitalive:
Unlike the nuclear battery version proposed in 2014, this version needs ongoing human attention.
Place it by a window‚Äîit needs sunlight during the day. Keep the room around 25¬∞C. Temperature swings shorten its life.
The person looking after it gets daily time with existential questions.
We won't know if it worked until it blinks again.
![LED that blinks once every 100 years ver 001, 2025](03-LED-that-blinks-once-every-100-years ver 001.jpeg)
![LED that blinks once every 100 years ver 001, 2025](01-LED-that-blinks-once-every-100-years ver 001.jpeg)
![The First Blink at Galaxy Coporation, 2026](100YearsBlink.jpg)

presentations.history:
In 2014, this was planned as [a public art installation](/works/led-that-blinks-once-every-100-years/2014-Prototype/). The jury asked twice to change it to blink once a year. No agreement was reached.
Twelve years later in 2026, the first version was built.

works.title: Hello 90
works.description: In Korea, bowing expresses greeting or gratitude. But when combined with extreme machismo, it becomes a fear response. Hello 90 is an interactive video installation.
overview: In Korea, bowing expresses greeting or gratitude. But when combined with extreme machismo, it becomes a fear response. A normal bow is 30-40 degrees; the extreme macho bow is a full 90 degrees‚Äîfaster, with a louder greeting. This bowing style is common among gangsters and military personnel, but also in college clubs and among K-pop idols.
Hello 90 is an interactive video installation where people on screen bow at 90 degrees when you enter.

works.title: "Prove It: For Mankind"
works.description: Air bending versus the Large Hadron Collider. Why do few care about air bending while nations spend billions on the LHC at CERN?
overview: A curatorial research project and exhibition plan for the Asian Culture Center opening in Gwangju, Korea. Air bending versus the Large Hadron Collider. Why do few care about air bending while nations spend billions on the LHC at CERN? Is this about pseudoscience versus real science? Or about what actually improves the world? What is "betterment"? Experts prove; people believe‚Äîbecause most can't understand either way. The project places different "proofs" side by side: air bending vs. LHC, a man hiking with an atomic clock to feel time, human echolocation by blind people, a Dynasphere machine generating love Qi for world peace, quantum consciousness, and more. *The exhibition was never realized due to a change in director.
![Prove It For Mankind Poster](01-Prove It For Mankind Poster.jpeg)

works.title: ANTI-Climax
works.description: A performance at the opening of MMCA Seoul. The show explored deconstructing the authority of previous artworks to create new ones.
overview: A performance at the opening of MMCA Seoul. Collaborating with actor Taeyoung Kang, actress Eun-ah Suh, and the band Idiotape, the show explored deconstructing the authority of previous artworks to create new ones. It began with LED poets spouting nonsense, moved through improvised confessions via computer chat, calling out every audience member's name, and flower-rope suicides, ending with loud music in the quiet museum. Deliberately clumsy graphics and fake sculptures were displayed prominently while technology stayed hidden. Only 3 of hundreds danced.

presentations.overview:
The Uranium Necklace is a necklace for people who wish to die, created by artist Hojun Song using actual uranium ore, gold, and stainless steel wire.
As part of the ‚ÄúEulji Drama‚Äù event, this program offers participants the opportunity to directly experience ‚Äúdeath tasting‚Äù by wearing the Uranium Necklace for 10 minutes.
Through one-on-one conversations with the artist about death, the event aims to explore clich√©d yet fundamental questions in a lighthearted manner.
A total of five participants will be selected, and each selected participant will be provided with a photograph of themselves wearing the Uranium Necklace.
The event will be live-streamed online, and voice modulation and mosaic masking are available upon the participant‚Äôs request.

works.title: The Strongest Weapon In The World
works.description: A series of attempts to build an indestructible weapon that does NOT attack. When struck with a hammer, it says 'I love you.'
overview: A series of attempts to build an indestructible weapon that does NOT attack. The first version, Weapons of Mass Happiness, was a heavy cast-aluminum sphere with a Geiger counter and a printer that outputs messages when triggered by nuclear explosion.
The second was built with K-SAD students, featuring letters engraved on cow bones‚Äîemphasizing that indestructible data is the ultimate weapon.
In 2010, the third version appeared: I Love You. Armored in thick SC45 steel with a piezo sensor inside, it says "I love you" when struck with a hammer.
